title: The counterintuitive way to be more persuasive - Niro Sivanathan

multiple-choice.question: What is the "dilution effect" in the context of consumer behavior?

options.label: A
options.text: The tendency to overvalue a product due to its high price.

options.label: B
options.text: The tendency to undervalue a product due to the presence of broken or inferior items.

options.label: C
options.text: The tendency to buy more products than needed due to discounts.

options.label: D
options.text: The tendency to avoid buying products due to fear of making a wrong decision.

multiple-choice.question: According to the speaker, what happens when we present both diagnostic and nondiagnostic information together?

options.label: A
options.text: The diagnostic information becomes more prominent.

options.label: B
options.text: The nondiagnostic information becomes more prominent.

options.label: C
options.text: The diagnostic information is diluted by the nondiagnostic information.

options.label: D
options.text: The nondiagnostic information is ignored.

multiple-choice.question: What is the psychological explanation for the dilution effect?

options.label: A
options.text: Averaging model, where our minds average out the information presented.

options.label: B
options.text: Adding model, where our minds add up the information presented.

options.label: C
options.text: Subtracting model, where our minds subtract the irrelevant information.

options.label: D
options.text: Multiplying model, where our minds multiply the relevant information.

multiple-choice.question: What was the result of the study on pharmaceutical ads, where participants were shown ads with both major and minor side effects?

options.label: A

options.label: B
options.text: Participants rated the drug's overall severity to be lower.

options.label: C
options.text: Participants showed no difference in their rating of the drug's severity.

options.label: D
options.text: Participants were less attracted to consuming the drug.

multiple-choice.question: What is the main takeaway from the speaker's talk on the dilution effect?

options.label: A
options.text: Quality is less important than quantity when it comes to presenting arguments.

options.label: B
options.text: Quality trumps quantity when it comes to presenting arguments.

options.label: C
options.text: The more arguments you present, the stronger your case will be.

options.label: D
options.text: The fewer arguments you present, the weaker your case will be.

options.label: D
options.text: Masking is a way of learning new skills, and autistic people do it to acquire new knowledge.

title: Can you solve the fantasy election riddle? - Dennis E. Shasha

multiple-choice.question: What is the problem with conducting a poll to predict the winner of the election between the troll and the tree statesman?

options.label: A
options.text: The voters are not willing to participate in the poll.

options.label: B
options.text: The voters are not willing to admit their true preference for the troll due to his controversial life choices.

options.label: C
options.text: The voters are not familiar with the candidates.

options.label: D
options.text: The voters are not interested in the election.

multiple-choice.question: How does the pollster use the silver coin to conduct an accurate poll?

options.label: A
options.text: By asking the voters to flip the coin and report their actual preference if it lands heads.

options.label: B
options.text: By asking the voters to flip the coin and report "troll" if it lands heads, and their actual preference if it lands tails.

options.label: C
options.text: By asking the voters to flip the coin and report "tree statesman" if it lands heads, and their actual preference if it lands tails.

options.label: D
options.text: By asking the voters to flip the coin and report their actual preference regardless of the outcome.

multiple-choice.question: What is the purpose of subtracting 100 troll votes from the total in the first poll?

options.label: A
options.text: To account for the voters who did not participate in the poll.

options.label: B
options.text: To account for the voters who reported "troll" due to the coin landing heads.

options.label: C
options.text: To account for the voters who reported "tree statesman" due to the coin landing tails.

options.label: D
options.text: To account for the voters who changed their minds after the poll.

multiple-choice.question: How does the pollster modify the polling method to account for the new challenge of voters being uncomfortable admitting their preference for either candidate?

options.label: A
options.text: By asking the voters to flip the coin once and report their actual preference.

options.label: B
options.text: By asking the voters to flip the coin twice and report their actual preference.

options.label: C
options.text: By asking the voters to flip the coin twice and report "troll" if they get two heads, "dragon" if they get two tails, and their actual preference otherwise.

options.label: D
options.text: By asking the voters to flip the coin twice and report "tree statesman" if they get two heads, "troll" if they get two tails, and their actual preference otherwise.

multiple-choice.question: What is the predicted outcome of the election based on the second poll?

options.label: A
options.text: The tree statesman wins by a margin of 55 to 45.

options.label: B
options.text: The troll wins by a margin of 55 to 45.

options.label: C
options.text: The dragon wins by a margin of 55 to 45.

options.label: D
options.text: The election is too close to call.

title: Uncovering the brain's biggest secret - Melanie E. Peffer

multiple-choice.question: What was the main idea behind the reticular theory of the nervous system?

options.label: A
options.text: The nervous system is composed of individual cells that transmit signals to each other.

options.label: B
options.text: The nervous system is a massive web of tissue that physically connects every nerve cell in the body.

options.label: C
options.text: The nervous system uses electrical impulses to control the body.

options.label: D
options.text: The nervous system is composed of a single, long nerve cell that transmits signals throughout the body.

multiple-choice.question: Who developed the staining technique known as the "black reaction" that allowed researchers to see the entire cell body of neurons?

options.label: A
options.text: Santiago Ramón y Cajal

options.label: B
options.text: Camillo Golgi

options.label: C
options.text: Charles Darwin

options.label: D
options.text: Louis Pasteur

multiple-choice.question: What was the major contribution of Santiago Ramón y Cajal to the field of neuroscience?

options.label: A
options.text: He developed the reticular theory of the nervous system.

options.label: B
options.text: He discovered the neuron doctrine, which proposed that the brain's tissue is made up of many discrete cells.

options.label: C
options.text: He improved Golgi's staining technique, allowing for more detailed images of neurons.

options.label: D
options.text: He discovered the role of electrical impulses in the nervous system.

multiple-choice.question: What technology further supported Cajal's hypothesis of the neuron doctrine in the mid-1900s?

options.label: A
options.text: Light microscopy

options.label: B
options.text: Electron microscopy

options.label: C
options.text: Fluorescence microscopy

options.label: D
options.text: Confocal microscopy

options.label: A

options.label: B
options.text: Signals jump from cell to cell in a linear chain of activation.

options.label: C
options.text: Signals are transmitted through a single, long nerve cell that spans the entire body.

options.label: D
options.text: Signals are converted between chemical and electrical signals as they travel from neuron to neuron.

title: Why didn’t this 2,000 year old body decompose? - Carolyn Marshall

multiple-choice.question: Why was the Lindow Man's body so well-preserved despite being over 2,000 years old?

options.label: A
options.text: The body was buried in a dry, hot environment.

options.label: B

options.label: C
options.text: The body was wrapped in a special cloth that prevented decay.

options.label: D
options.text: The body was embalmed with chemicals.

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary role of microbes in the decomposition process?

options.label: A
options.text: To break down complex organic materials into simpler compounds.

options.label: B
options.text: To absorb nutrients from the soil and excrete waste.

options.label: C
options.text: To release enzymes that trigger chemical reactions.

options.label: D
options.text: To consume carbon and nutrients from the soil.

options.label: A
options.text: Mineralization

options.label: B
options.text: Oxidation

options.label: C
options.text: Decomposition

options.label: D
options.text: Fermentation

multiple-choice.question: Why do peat bogs, like the one where the Lindow Man was found, prevent decomposition?

options.label: A
options.text: They are too hot and dry for microbes to function.

options.label: B
options.text: They are too cold and acidic for microbes to function, and the Sphagnum mosses bind to nitrogen, depriving the area of nutrients.

options.label: C
options.text: They are too wet and humid for microbes to function.

options.label: D
options.text: They are too salty for microbes to function.

multiple-choice.question: What was unique about the Lindow Man's last meal that allowed scholars to determine what he ate?

options.label: A
options.text: It was a large meal that was difficult to digest.

options.label: B
options.text: It was a meal that was high in fiber and nutrients.

options.label: C
options.text: It was a meal that was charred and undigested.

options.label: D
options.text: It was a meal that was eaten quickly.

title: What if every satellite suddenly disappeared? - Moriba Jah

multiple-choice.question: What would be the immediate effect on global positioning, navigation, and timing services if all artificial satellites were to suddenly disappear?

options.label: A
options.text: They would become more accurate due to reduced interference.

options.label: B
options.text: They would be unaffected, as they rely on ground-based systems.

options.label: C
options.text: They would entirely cease to function.

options.label: D
options.text: They would experience minor disruptions, but overall remain operational.

options.label: A
options.text: They would become more efficient due to reduced reliance on technology.

options.label: B
options.text: They would be unaffected, as they rely on manual systems.

options.label: C
options.text: They would fragment, leaving people to survive on whatever is locally available.

options.label: D
options.text: They would experience minor disruptions, but overall remain operational.

multiple-choice.question: What is one potential scenario that could lead to the same results as the sudden disappearance of all artificial satellites?

options.label: A
options.text: A massive cyberattack on satellite systems.

options.label: B
options.text: A solar flare so strong it fries satellite circuitry.

options.label: C
options.text: A global power outage affecting ground-based systems.

options.label: D
options.text: A physical attack on satellite launch facilities.

options.label: C

options.label: D

options.label: C

options.label: D

options.label: C
options.text: Only the wife could demand a divorce

options.label: C
options.text: Without proving harm, and without the other's consent

options.text: The act of giving advice to someone

options.text: The feeling of empathy towards someone

title: Can you solve the basketball robot riddle? - Dan Katz

options.label: B
options.text: To ensure the human wins every game

options.label: C
options.text: To give the human a 50% chance of winning each match

options.label: D
options.text: To make the game as short as possible

options.label: B
options.text: It gives the human an unfair advantage

options.label: C
options.text: It makes the game too long

options.label: D
options.text: It makes the game too short

multiple-choice.question: What is a geometric series, and how is it used in this problem?

options.label: A
options.text: A geometric series is a finite sum of numbers, and it is used to calculate the total probability of the human winning

options.label: B
options.text: A geometric series is an infinite sum of numbers, and it is used to calculate the total probability of the human winning

options.label: C
options.text: A geometric series is a finite sum of numbers, and it is used to calculate the total probability of the robot winning

options.label: D
options.text: A geometric series is an infinite sum of numbers, and it is used to calculate the total probability of the robot winning

multiple-choice.question: What is the formula for the sum of a geometric series, and how is it used in this problem?

options.label: A
options.text: The formula is a / (1 - r), and it is used to calculate the total probability of the human winning

options.label: B
options.text: The formula is a / (1 + r), and it is used to calculate the total probability of the human winning

options.label: C
options.text: The formula is a / (1 - r), and it is used to calculate the total probability of the robot winning

options.label: D
options.text: The formula is a / (1 + r), and it is used to calculate the total probability of the robot winning

multiple-choice.question: What is the final solution for the Dunk-O-Matic's probability of success, and what is the condition for a fair game?

options.label: A
options.text: The solution is q = p, and a fair game is possible for any value of p

options.label: B
options.text: The solution is q = p / (1 - p), and a fair game is possible only if p is less than or equal to 50%

options.label: C
options.text: The solution is q = p / (1 - p), and a fair game is possible for any value of p

options.label: D
options.text: The solution is q = p, and a fair game is possible only if p is less than or equal to 50%
